title: 111_hr230
content: The Act may be cited as the "Housing Opportunity and Mortgage Equity Act of 2009" and includes provisions for affordable refinancing mortgages and new mortgages. The Federal National Mortgage Association and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation are required to purchase and securitize qualified refinancing mortgages and new mortgages on single-family housing as per the policies set by the Director of the Federal Housing Finance Agency. If a lender offers a mortgage for purchase, the enterprise must determine whether to proceed. The Director of the Federal Housing Finance Agency will establish requirements for the purchase of qualified mortgages by enterprises. If a lender offers a mortgage for purchase, the enterprise will determine if it meets the criteria for a qualified mortgage and proceed with the purchase. The Director of the Federal Housing Finance Agency will establish requirements for the purchase of qualified mortgages by enterprises. If a lender offers a mortgage that meets the criteria for a qualified mortgage, the enterprise will make a commitment to purchase it. The enterprise must also establish a procedure for advance approval of lenders for the purchase of qualified mortgages. The enterprise will establish a procedure for lenders to receive advance approval for the purchase of qualified mortgages. A qualified mortgage is defined as either a qualified refinancing mortgage or a qualified new mortgage. A qualified refinancing mortgage is a mortgage for a one to four-family dwelling that the mortgagor must occupy as their principal residence. The mortgage must be for a one to four-family dwelling, including a condominium or cooperative ownership. The mortgagor must occupy the property as their principal residence. The loan amount must be used to pay off existing first mortgage debt for the purchase of the property. The refinancing mortgage must be used to pay off existing first mortgage debt on the same property that was originated on or before January 1, 2008. The refinancing mortgage must pay off existing first mortgage debt on the same property originated on or before January 1, 2008. The new mortgage must have a fixed interest rate not exceeding 4.0% annually and a term to maturity of not less than a specified period. The refinancing mortgage must have a fixed interest rate not exceeding 4.0% annually and a term to maturity of 30-40 years. Underwriting standards set by the Director must be met. The refinancing mortgage must have a fixed interest rate not exceeding 4.0% annually and a term to maturity of 30-40 years. Underwriting standards set by the Director must be met, and all prepayment penalties and fees related to default on the underlying mortgage must be waived. The refinancing mortgage must have a fixed interest rate not exceeding 4.0% annually and a term to maturity of 30-40 years. All penalties for prepayment or refinancing of the underlying mortgage, as well as fees and penalties related to default or delinquency, must be waived for the qualified new mortgage. The term "qualified new mortgage" refers to a mortgage that meets specific requirements, including terms outlined in subparagraphs (A), (B), (D), and (E) of paragraph (2), being used for the purchase of the property subject to the mortgage, and being originated on or after the enactment of the Act. The principal loan amount secured by the mortgage must be used to purchase the property subject to the qualified new mortgage, which must be originated after the enactment of this Act. Enterprises can establish exceptions to underwriting standards, including downpayment and credit rating requirements, to align with established standards. Each enterprise must establish exceptions to underwriting standards, such as downpayment and credit rating requirements, to align with the standards set by the Director for purchasing and securitizing qualified refinancing mortgages and new mortgages. The enterprises must set exceptions to underwriting standards to align with the Director's requirements for purchasing and securitizing qualified refinancing and new mortgages. They must set aside qualified mortgages and issue securities based on them, subject to approval by the Secretary of the Treasury. Securities can be in the form of debt obligations or trust certificates. The enterprises can issue securities based on qualified mortgages, with approval from the Secretary of the Treasury. These securities can be in the form of debt obligations or trust certificates, with maturities and interest rates determined by the enterprise with the Secretary's approval. Securities issued under this subsection are exempt to the same extent as other securities. Securities issued under this subsection have maturities and interest rates approved by the enterprise with the Secretary's approval. They are considered exempt securities similar to those guaranteed by the United States. The subsection deems securities exempt like those guaranteed by the United States. Mortgages must ensure timely payments for securities issued. Enterprises must provide required disclosure. Mortgages set aside must cover principal and interest payments for securities issued. Enterprises must disclose that the securities are not guaranteed by the United States. The Federal Reserve will establish a credit facility to provide credit to enterprises at interest rates similar to Treasury securities. Securities issued by enterprises must clearly state they are not guaranteed by the United States. The Federal Reserve will establish a credit facility for enterprises to access credit at rates comparable to Treasury securities. The requirement for enterprises to purchase mortgages will not apply to mortgages offered after December 31, 2010. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines the Director as the head of the Federal Housing Finance Agency, the enterprise as the Federal National Mortgage Association and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, and the Secretary as the Secretary of the Treasury.
